results.title: [Ted Parsons Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
Ted Parsons was a keen amateur filmmaker of the 1940s to 1960s. Ted’s films feature life in and around the Victorian regional city of Wangaratta post-war. This was a period of prosperity and optimism largely due to a successful textile industry that took Wangaratta from a small country town to major rural city, declared in 1959.

Ted captures the many sporting and social events, venues and clubs, holidays and travel along with scenes of everyday life. The collection also shows the broader issues faced by country people such as the regular flooding events around the Ovens and King Rivers.

Wangaratta’s success story as a manufacturing town traces the path of post-war migration and the accompanying growth of Australia’s economy, which makes these films particularly interesting.

The Ted Parsons Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s grandson Barry Parsons. The films have been made on 16mm film.

This film captures the visit of Australian champion golfer Peter Thomson to the Wangaratta Golf Club in 1956. As shown by the poster in the film, Thomson teaches a golf clinic to an avid crowd. At the time, Thomson had won the British Open twice, and would go on to win it a total of five times - he was the first Australian golfer to win the championship and the only man to have won it in three consecutive years in the twentieth century (1954, 1955 and 1956).

The film shows off the lovely surrounds of the Golf Club set against the backdrop of the town itself and in particular, the backyards of houses. The golfers are particularly smartly dressed in clothes suitable for striding around the course with their golf bags and trolleys, the women in pleated or full mid calf skirts and the men tucking ties into shirts and full 1950s style trousers.

In this film, we can feel the atmosphere of Wangaratta in the post war period - a growing, prosperous community with an increasingly cosmopolitan outlook thanks to an influx of migrants to the area.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 title card ‘Wangaratta Golf Club ‘
00:00:25:00 four golfers appraoching a green wearing stylish golfing clothes of the era
00:01:09:00 golfers shaking hands
00:01:38:00 a particularly nice pink hat on a golfer and an example of the 1950s style golf cart
00:02:09:00 more examples of golfing fashion including sun visors
00:03:19:00 a woman carries her cardigan and bag on her golf cart
00:04:02:00 a closer look at a golf bag in a cart
00:04:27:00 post golf drinks at the clubhouse
00:04:51:00 advertising leaflet for ‘Exhibition Golf and Clinic by Peter Thomson (Dual British Open Champion)’, described as the ‘Greatest Golf Day in History’ followed by scenes of the golf clinic in action
00:04:53:00 a woman with a camera taking shots of Thomson as he conducts the golf clinic
00:05:55:00 views of the large crowd at the golf clinic
00:06:30:00 close-up of Thomson’s golfclubs engraved with his name in protective covers with pom poms
00:06:39:00 a man tees off with a cigarette in his mouth
00:07:00:00 the crowd of onlookers surge forward following a player whlist holding up the boundary rope
00:07:44:00 everyone focused on the player as he lines up a shot
00:08:25:00 Thomson giving lessons on how to grip the golf club in the golf clinic
00:09:45:00 close-up of the crowd
00:11:14:00 local golfers say hello to the camera with lovely old houses behind the golf course
00:12:48:00 a golfer in a 1950s style hat likely to be a ‘Stetson’ and his tie tucked into his shirt leans casually on his golfclub before we see him toss his cigarette stub behind him
00:13:07:00 a refreshment tent set up near the golf course clubhouse with people relaxed
00:13:42:00 ladies and beers at the refreshment tent
00:13:50:00 the camera pans an attentative crowd of onlookers
00:14:47:00 the large crowd follow the play under huge lovely trees on the golf course

group_siblings.title: [Taronga Park; Sydney Harbour Bridge; The Great Barrier Reef; Peeping at Perth]
group_siblings.creator_credit: Eric Merton, Kodak Cinegraph and Perier Films

results.title: [Taronga Park; Sydney Harbour Bridge; The Great Barrier Reef; Peeping at Perth]
results.creator_credit: Eric Merton, Kodak Cinegraph and Perier Films
results.brief_description:
This film contains four short tourism films edited together, possibly by Ted Parsons.

The first film shows Taronga Zoological Park in Sydney, New South Wales, which was opened to the public in 1916 as a popular tourist destination. The segment shows various species of animals, in particular Australian marsupials (including kangaroos and koalas) and reptiles (including a goanna and a green python). The animals are introduced with title cards.

The second section of film shows the Sydney Harbour Bridge and Sydney beaches. The film shows the arched bridge, including views from the top of it, as well as surfing at Bondi, coastal views of Palm Beach and surf lifesaving at Manly.

The third segment shows close-ups of rockpools by the Great Barrier Reef, including crustaceans, sea snails and starfish. It also shows wildlife, including birds and turtles, along the beaches in Queensland.

In the fourth section, the highlights of Perth, Western Australia are shown. The film shows views across the Perth city, King’s Park, the buildings in London Court and the grand buildings of the University of Western Australia.
results.title_for_label: [Taronga Park; Sydney Harbour Bridge; The Great Barrier Reef; Peeping at Perth]

results.title: [London, 1963 - 1964]
results.brief_description:
This silent, black-and-white footage of some of the major landmarks of London was shot in 1963–1964 by Australian photographer Robert Lennox Suggett.

Opens with the Royal Marines Band playing, filmed as they march past the Duke of York Column and Waterloo Steps.

00:00:46:00 then Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, Alec Douglas-Home, farewelling a visitor on the steps of Number 10 Downing Street (the headquarters of British government).

00:01:11:00 camera pans down Nelson’s Column (a monument in Trafalgar Square, central London, commemorating Admiral Horatio Nelson.) We then see scenes of Trafalgar Square, with the National Gallery building and fountain both visible.

00:01:22:00 camera lingers on the equestrian statue of King Charles I, with the church of St Martin-in-the-Fields in the background.

00:01:28:00 London traffic, with the camera focussing especially on cabs (taxis).

00:01:43:00 the Admiralty Arch.

00:01:49:00 double-decker London bus in front of some classic 1960’s style adverstising signs in Piccadilly Circus, with the Eros statue visible.

00:02:04:00 Eros statue in close-up.

00:02:22:00 Underground (railway) sign in close-up, followed by scenes in the Underground itself; ticket queues, escalators, and a train coming into a platform.

00:02:46:00 “Piccadilly Circus” station sign visible on the wall of the train tunnel

The film ends with footage of the tunnel, shot from the moving train.

group_siblings.title: [Construction of the Water Tower at Fletcher Jones Factory, Warrnambool, 1967]

production_dates.notes: Creation date recorded on donated film can.

results.title: [Construction of the Water Tower at Fletcher Jones Factory, Warrnambool, 1967]
results.brief_description:
The Fletcher Jones factory and Gardens at 61–81 Flaxman Street, Warrnambool (established 1948) are famous local landmarks and symbolic of the radical approach to industrial relations and the provision of workplace amenities taken by the famous Australian company. The complex, including the Water Tower, was listed on the Victorian Heritage Register in 2006 in recognition of its historic and social significance which notes “…the unusual and successful integration of surplus military structures, buildings and modernist facade in a factory setting. They reflect the resourcefulness and dynamism of Fletcher Jones in the use of war surplus structures and objects during a time of building material shortages.”

The forty-metre-high water tower – built for fire protection and as a booster system – was designed and supervised by Ralph Jones Construction Engineering Services between 1965–1967. [Source: University of Melbourne Archives: Ralph Jones Water Tower Submission and Business Papers].

This silent, black-and-white footage of the tower’s construction was photographed by Australian photographer Robert Lennox Suggett. It is a unique historic documentary record of the construction of an iconic feature of Warrnambool’s – and Victoria’s – industrial heritage.

results.title: [Robert Lennox Suggett Collection]
results.brief_description: This collection consists of two short, silent 16mm films made by Australian photographer Robert Lennox Suggett in the 1960s. One shows the construction of the water tower in Warrnambool, Victoria, in 1967, while the other features footage shot in London between 1963 and 1964.
results.description: This collection consists of two short, silent 16mm films made by Australian photographer Robert Lennox Suggett in the 1960s. One shows the construction of the water tower in Warrnambool, Victoria, in 1967, while the other features footage shot in London between 1963 and 1964.

group_works.title: [Construction of the Water Tower at Fletcher Jones Factory, Warrnambool, 1967]

results.title: [Safe] = Safe [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Todd Haynes, Lauren Zalaznick, Christine Vachon and Chemical Films
results.brief_description: ‘Homemaker’ Carol White lives an ensconced life with her husband and step-son in the wealthy outer suburbs of Los Angeles. Yet her domestic bliss is marred by allergic reactions which gradually worsen into severe attacks and exhaustion triggered by sources as disparate as car exhaust, beauty products and bug spray. Failing to find any medical explanation for her maladies, her doctor refers her to a psychiatrist, who suggests that her physical ailments are psychosomatic and that she is in a state of hysteria - a theory echoed by her callous and increasingly frustrated husband. Carol herself becomes convinced that she is suffering from ‘multiple chemical sensitivity’ or ‘20th century disease’- an immune system disorder which make the body vulnerable to the low-level toxins and forms of pollution that are part of modern life. Unable to adequately perform her expected gender role, she withdraws to an expensive New Age retreat where the community’s guru champions a dubious regimen of diet, climate control, introspection, and self-love. Yet this move does little to improve her physical or mental state. Is it possible that the illness that so disrupts the order of her world is far less dangerous than the cure to restore it? Suggesting parallels between Carol’s illness and AIDS, Hayne’s offers a sharp critique of both traditional and alternative approaches that attempt to pigeonhole ‘baffling’ illnesses to further their own agendas. Cast includes Julianne Moore, Peter Friedman, Susan Norman, Xander Berkeley and James LeGros.

Failing to find any medical explanation for her maladies, her doctor refers her to a psychiatrist, who suggests that her physical ailments are psychosomatic and that she is in a state of hysteria - a theory echoed by her callous and increasingly frustrated husband. Carol herself becomes convinced that she is suffering from ‘multiple chemical sensitivity’ or ‘20th century disease’- an immune system disorder which make the body vulnerable to the low-level toxins and forms of pollution that are part of modern life. Unable to adequately perform her expected gender role, she withdraws to an expensive New Age retreat where the community’s guru champions a dubious regimen of diet, climate control, introspection, and self-love. Yet this move does little to improve her physical or mental state. Is it possible that the illness that so disrupts the order of her world is far less dangerous than the cure to restore it? Suggesting parallels between Carol’s illness and AIDS, Hayne’s offers a sharp critique of both traditional and alternative approaches that attempt to pigeonhole ‘baffling’ illnesses to further their own agendas. Cast includes Julianne Moore, Peter Friedman, Susan Norman, Xander Berkeley and James LeGros.

results.title: [Royal District Nursing Service TV Ad]
results.brief_description:
The Royal District Nursing Service was founded in 1885 and was originally called the Melbourne District Nursing Service. An initiative led by the Reverend Charles Strong, the organisation was established to nurse the sick, poor and disadvantaged in their own homes. By the early 1920s the nurses were treating 25,000 patients per year and had established a convalescent institution, the After-Care Home (later Hospital) in Collingwood. In 1966 the organisation became the Royal District Nursing Service.

This television advertisement is an appeal for donations to the Royal District Nursing Service. Filmed in black and white, the advertisement shows a nurse visiting various patients in the community, including babies, the elderly, disabled and blind. A voiceover describes the valuable contribution the nurses make to the community, with over 300,000 visits per year - enough patients to fill the largest public hospital.

results.title: [Remix: Victorian Road Signs]
results.brief_description:
Produced using footage from the ACMI Collection, this remix features painted road signs from locations all over Victoria, interspliced with shots of native wildlife and natural wilderness.

Road signs in order of appearance are: Halls Gap, Horsham, McKenzie Falls, Murray Valley Highway, Corryon, Walwa, Tumbarumba, Jingellic, Upper Kiewa Valley Road, Mt Beauty, Rocky Valley, Princes Highway, Gembrook, Cockatoo, Whitfield, Wangaratta, Ferntree Gully, Wilson’s Promontory National Park, Ovens River, Beechworth, San Remo, Porepunkah, Murray River, Anglesea and Great Ocean Road.

results.title: [Remix: Transport]
results.brief_description: This short film is a remix of archival footage from the ACMI Collection, focusing on public transport in Victoria. The remix contains footage of trams, trains, Flinders Street Station and city streets in Melbourne.
